essential_elements.guidance: Must have track record in genre. Netflix prefers proven showrunners over first-timers. For prestige plays, Emmy/Golden Globe credentials matter.
Must have Netflix relationship (overall deal, first-look, or proven track record). Cold pitches from unknown prodcos rarely succeed.

essential_elements.importance: High for limited series, Medium for ongoing
essential_elements.guidance: A-list talent critical for limited series and prestige plays. For ongoing series, can cast after greenlight if showrunner is strong.
Pilot script required for drama series. Full scripts for limited series preferred. Bible must show 3-season arc for ongoing series.
Must be realistic and competitive. Netflix compares cost-per-hour vs projected viewing. Prestige plays can justify higher budgets with awards potential.

common_mistakes: Cold outreach to executives without prodco partner
Vague 'we'll figure it out in development' approach
Unrealistic budgets (too high or suspiciously low)
No clear global hook or international appeal
Pitching to wrong executive (film vs series, US vs international)
No comp titles or market positioning
Unclear IP rights or life rights status

success_formula.for_limited_series: A-list talent + proven showrunner + tight script (6-8 eps) + awards positioning + production company with Netflix deal = 70% greenlight rate
success_formula.for_drama_series: Showrunner with track record + production company with Netflix deal + pilot + bible with 3-season arc + global hook = 50% greenlight rate
success_formula.for_overall_deal: Proven track record (2+ hits) + multiple project ideas + strategic fit with Netflix priorities + competitive offer from rival streamer = negotiating leverage
